report_title: Automobile Electronics Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Automobile electronics manufacturers produce motor vehicle parts that have or operate with small components that control and direct an electric current. Companies commonly manufacture lighting systems, electrical wiring, electrical control units, sensors, electronic ignition systems and driver displays. Auto electronics manufacturers have faltered through the current period, especially as the pandemic and high interest rates inject uncertainty into consumer markets. Revenue has ebbed at an expected CAGR of 1.6% to $26.8 billion through the current period, despite a 3.1% rebound in 2024, where profit reached 5.8%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: High interest rates threaten automotive supply chains
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Higher interest rates following the pandemic have contributed to more expensive automobile loans, discouraging purchases, especially from lower-income buyers. Higher interest rates have also corresponded with poor consumer confidence, making individuals less willing to purchase new vehicles. Even so, consumer confidence is rebounding in 2024. This trend will contribute to stronger demand for new cars, especially as automakers take advantage of pent-up demand for travel.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The rising popularity of electric vehicles benefits auto electronics manufacturers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Automobile electronics manufacturers faced severe supply chain shortages following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. The prices of most key inputs, including steel, cobalt, copper, silicon, semiconductors and rare earth metals noticeably increased, contributing to profit declines. Companies have largely prioritized supply chain localization following these disruptions. Automakers have historically relied on tier 1 suppliers, like automobile electronics manufacturers, to purchase and package chips.

Automakers have integrated increasingly complex features, formerly reserved for luxury vehicles, in more affordable, base car models to attract consumers and appeal to greater demand for safety and connectivity features. Manufacturers have increasingly focused on strategic partnerships with technology companies to facilitate technological expansion in automobiles. Increased innovation and closer partnerships with automakers also protect companies from import penetration.

Automobile electronics differentiate between innovation-focused and process-focused manufacturing operations. Process-focused products are largely mass-produced, generic products. These generic products face intense competition from manufacturers across Asia and South America that take advantage of lower labor and production costs. Mexico, China and Taiwan have dominant positions in these markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Electric vehicles will alter the industry's landscape
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Electric vehicles don't need traditional alternators, spark plugs, cranking motors or cable sets to start and operate, potentially eliminating a major demand source. However, electric vehicles require a series of advanced components to function with batteries and electric drivetrains. This shift will create ample opportunities for start-ups and other entrants but may cause companies focused on parts associated with combustion vehicles to falter.

Product innovation will remain a driving force across the automotive supply chain and vehicle manufacturers will increasingly prioritize new electronic features. Many innovations will focus on increased safety and pair with increased electric and hybrid vehicle production. Manufacturers must improve the comfort and reliability of regenerative brakes to make them competitive with traditional friction brakes. In general, automotive electronics manufacturers will play a massive role in all future automobile innovations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Outsourcing will pose a major threat to domestic manufacturers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Automobile electronics manufacturers have faced intense competition from a wide range of foreign competitors. These foreign producers offer domestic buyers high-quality, price-competitive automobile electronics. In particular, many prominent automakers have outsourced production to Mexico. Many members of the automotive supply chain will similarly relocate to Mexico to cut transportation costs and more closely collaborate with their supply chains.

Larger profitable companies will acquire small companies with specific specialties and innovative products to facilitate lower-cost mass production, blurring the line between Tier 1 and Tier 2 suppliers. Persistent foreign competition will also spur consolidation. Leading manufacturers will target competitors with strong positions in niches, especially high-tech products associated with electric vehicles. Many companies will also partner with technology companies and research institutions to test other technologies, like head-up displays and autonomous driving.

industry_definition: Automobile electronics manufacturers produce motor vehicle parts that have or operate with small components that control and direct an electric current. Companies commonly manufacture lighting systems, electrical wiring, electrical control units, sensors, electronic ignition systems and driver displays.

negative_impact_factors: Oil and natural gas price index

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Oil and natural gas price index
threats: Low Outlier Growth: New car sales

key_trends: The rising popularity and production of electric vehicles is a major industry trend that is both an opportunity and threat
Increasing outsourcing and offshoring of production to lower-cost countries like Mexico
Consolidation through mergers and acquisitions, especially of smaller innovative companies by larger players
Prioritization of product innovation focused on safety, connectivity and integration with new electric vehicle technologies
Localization and reshoring of supply chains following pandemic-related disruptions

factors_increased_barrier: Accommodate environmental requirements - Manufacturers must adhere to a wide range of environmental standards. CAFE regulations contribute to higher demand for more energy-efficient components.
factors_decreased_barrier: Develop effective cost controls - Continued pressure from the assemblers to reduce prices will require effective cost controls. Manufacturers must offer competitive prices to differentiate.

basis_points.basis_description: Product innovation and expenditure on research and development are required to gain competitiveness.

basis_points.basis_title: Leverage the company's degree of globalization
basis_points.basis_description: To expand, companies must have global presence as sourcing of parts is fast becoming global.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Auto electronics manufacturers purchase various raw and semifinished materials, like copper, aluminum, rubber, semiconductors and electronic components. Companies also purchase lithium, cobalt, rare earth metals and other minerals essential in energy transition. Purchases make up the majority of expenses for manufacturers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Companies invest more in skilled labor
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Automobile electronics manufacturers depend heavily on engineers and production workers for product development, assembly and supply and distribution management. Wage expenses have steadily increased through the current period. Manufacturers have focused on research and development to keep up with shifting consumer trends.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Companies invest more in skilled labor
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Automobile electronics manufacturers depend heavily on engineers and production workers for product development, assembly and supply and distribution management. Wage expenses have steadily increased through the current period.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Companies endured major supply chain disruptions
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Companies endured major supply chain disruptions following the pandemic and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. Manufacturers face global shortages, especially regarding semiconductors, leading to major price increases after decades of falling prices.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Automobile electronics manufacturers primarily rely on automakers for sales, often holding supply contracts with various automakers. Demand largely hinges on consumer spending trends and new car sales. Stronger economic conditions will create demand for new cars, contributing to higher demand for a range of automotive products, including electronics.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Higher input costs pose a major threat
volatility_points.volatility_description: Higher input costs pose a major threat to auto electronics manufacturers. Companies endured severe input price fluctuations through the latter half of the current period, contributing to limited profit expansion. Higher semiconductor prices pose a long-term challenge to domestic manufacturers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Climbing external competition remains a major threat
volatility_points.volatility_description: Climbing external competition also remains a major threat to long-term profit growth. Many companies have established offshore facilities in Mexico, China, Honduras and other lower-wage regions to undercut US producers. Companies also face competition from established automotive and tech powerhouses like Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Germany.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Companies invest more in skilled labor
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers have focused on research and development to keep up with shifting consumer trends. Companies are innovating new, advanced features, like head-up displays (HUD), advanced safety systems, cruise controls and electronics to support the proliferation of electric vehicles.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Companies have automated many low-wage production positions
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Companies have automated many low-wage production positions, requiring skilled employees to manage and operate machinery.

FAQs.question: What are the key financial benchmarks for the automobile electronics manufacturing industry?
FAQs.answer: According to the report, some key financial benchmarks are: Profit Margin of 5.8% (higher than sector average), Average Wage of $62,169 (lower than sector average), and Purchases being the largest cost at 62.1% of Revenue.

FAQs.question: What are the major cost drivers for companies in this industry?
FAQs.answer: The major cost drivers mentioned are: 1) Purchases of raw materials like copper, aluminum, semiconductors which have faced supply disruptions and price increases. 2) Skilled labor costs like engineers and production workers which have increased as companies invest more in R&D. 3) Volatile conditions limiting profit expansion due to input cost fluctuations and rising competition.

FAQs.question: How have financial ratios like profitability and leverage trended for this industry?
FAQs.answer: The report provides trends for various financial ratios: Profitability ratios like EBIT/Revenue and EBITDA/Revenue have declined over the 3-year and 5-year periods compared to longer-term averages. Leverage ratios like Debt/Net Worth have increased over the recent periods, indicating higher debt levels. Coverage ratios like Interest Coverage remain healthy. Liquidity ratios like Current Ratio have declined but remain at adequate levels.

FAQs.question: What are some key operating metrics and their trends for this industry?
FAQs.answer: Some key operating metrics provided are: Revenue per Employee has declined from over $500k in 2014-2016 to around $450k projected for 2024-2030. Wages as a percentage of Revenue has increased from 11.6% in 2015 to 13.6-13.7% projected for 2023-2030. Imports as a percentage of Demand has increased from around 49% in 2014-2016 to over 54% projected for 2022 onwards, indicating rising import penetration.
